Ignat Insarov (Dec 17 2024 at 06:43):

Tom Leinster said:

The page geometry and font I use these days come directly from CUP. It's what they specified when I wrote Basic Category Theory and Entropy and Diversity.

Ahaha, I see. So it is cambridge7A.cls that is to blame. Well, let us investigate the facts then. Let us consider _Basic Category Theory_ as given by the source code on arXiv and by the printed book.

What page size does cambridge7A.cls specify?

    128 \DeclareOption{a4paper}
    129   {\setlength\paperheight {297mm}%
    130    \setlength\paperwidth  {210mm}}

This is the A4 paper size.

What page size is the actual printed book?

Here is the book's page on the official Cambridge University Press shop. What does it say about the dimensions of the book?

Product details

  • Date Published: September 2014
  • format: Hardback
  • isbn: 9781107044241
  • length: 190 pages
  • dimensions: 235 x 156 x 15 mm
  • weight: 0.4kg
  • contains: 100 exercises
  • availability: Available

(Emphasis mine.)

Upon inspection of samples available from the same web site (say this one), we confirm that pages are about 228 × 152 millimetres in size (so they sink by a few millimetres below the edge of the hard cover). This is the American Royal paper size.

conclusion

Tom, you have been misled. In fact, Cambridge University Press did not publish your book in the same paper size as the style they have given you suggests. Observe however that page layout is very nearly the same between the printed and arXiv version — they only cropped the margins.

but anyway

What use cases are you aiming to support?

We have found 4 use cases so far:

  • reading on computer screen
  • reading on a printout
  • reading in a book
  • reading on projector screen

Of these only «reading in a book» seems to require wide margins to be provided at type setting stage, for scribbling. But on this use case Cambridge University Press has already let you down. If you want to have wide margins on a printout, it is easily accomplished by setting 80% scale in page setup, so this use case does not need any special support at type setting stage. At the same time, narrower margins are more cost effective since you can more easily squeeze two or even four pages on one A4 page to be printed out. On screen, scribbling does not seem to be a prominent use case since most software do not support it. In any case, to allow for liberal scribbling, a wide front margin is enough — there is no need to make all four margins unusually wide.

As we can now see, cropping the margins of a PDF file is not a trivial task. Firstly, you have to come up with good looking geometry — by trial and error. Then, there are problems along the way, like dying hyperlinks and outline. Among the four persons who said something about it (me, you, Mike and Matteo) we have exactly zero reproducible cases of success reported. This is where your support as a type setter is needed.

The wide margins of the arXiv version of Basic Category Theory and of the current PDF version of Axiomatic Set Theory are anything but common in type setting. If you know for sure that most of your readers are best served with wide margins on all sides, then of course you should go with wide margins. It would be surprising for me to learn that this is so — I cannot recall any printed book that would have had such wide margins on all sides nor any style guide that would call for it.

Tom Leinster said:

As I said, I hope to arXiv some version of the set theory notes one day.

And I have heard you (and John, to whose message I attached a cat picture). You also said that what stands in the way of making the source code available is the comments, to which I answered that you may try to remove comments automatically. I understand that there are other edits you will need to make before you see the book as «done». But maybe you can be persuaded to remove comments and then publish the source code provisionally? There is some advantage to having a sparrow in your hand while waiting for a crane in the sky to become available.

Riley Shahar (Dec 17 2024 at 17:39):

@Ignat Insarov to be honest, if I were you I would stop asking about this. We would like to create a mathematical culture in which it is relatively painless for experts to do the free labor of sharing their course notes with the rest of the world, who unlike their students or institutions do not pay for the use of their time and expertise. If the expectation is that anyone who publishes their notes is expected to either publish the source---which is often messy, unreadable, and whose publication is not a standard in any field of publishing in the world---or to publish new versions of the pdf catering to the formatting preferences of everyone who sends them a message, then I think you will quickly find that people stop publicly advertising their notes in the first place. (Or they stop participating in forums like this Zulip.)

As a student growing up now, (despite everything that's horrible about academia these days) I feel really lucky to live in a time where I can access world-class exposition and research, from my laptop in a coffee shop, as it is being published. We don't want to put extra burdens on the people who actually produce the artifacts that enable that culture. You asked once and got a polite no, which is already more than you were owed; anything after that seems excessive to me.
